sub_topic: Time dilation in a moving frame of reference
message_1: "Calculate the time dilation experienced by a spaceship traveling at 0.8c relative to Earth, where the spaceship mission lasts 5 years according to its on-board clocks. How much time will have passed on Earth during the mission, assuming no acceleration or deceleration during travel?"
message_2:
To calculate the time dilation experienced by a spaceship traveling at 0.8c relative to Earth, we can use the time dilation formula derived from the theory of special relativity:

t' = t / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where:
t' is the time experienced by the observer on Earth (the dilated time),
t is the proper time experienced by the spaceship (5 years in this case),
v is the relative velocity of the spaceship (0.8c),
c is the speed of light (approximately 3.0 x 10^8 m/s).

First, we need to calculate the factor inside the square root:

1 - v^2/c^2 = 1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2 = 1 - 0.64

Now, we can plug this value into the time dilation formula:

t' = 5 years / sqrt(1 - 0.64) = 5 years / sqrt(0.36)

t' = 5 years / 0.6 = 25/3 years â‰ˆ 8.33 years

So, during the 5-year mission according to the spaceship's on-board clocks, approximately 8.33 years will have passed on Earth.
